title: 107_s956
content: The "Child Passenger Safety Act" requires the use of safety belts and child restraint systems by children. The "Child Passenger Safety Act" mandates the use of safety belts and child restraint systems for children under the age of 16 in passenger vehicles. The law defines child safety restraint requirements and specifies the use of child safety seats that meet federal safety standards. The "Child Passenger Safety Act" requires the use of safety belts and child restraint systems for children under 16 in passenger vehicles. The Act defines terms like motor vehicle, multipurpose passenger vehicle, and passenger car based on specific criteria outlined in federal regulations. The Act also specifies the definition of a passenger motor vehicle and safety belt requirements for different types of vehicles. In fiscal year 2005, if a State has not enacted a child safety restraint law, the Secretary will transfer 4 percent of funds to implement a statewide child and passenger safety education program. The program includes instruction on proper seating positions for children in airbag-equipped vehicles and promoting the use of child restraint systems. In fiscal years 2006 and beyond, if a State has not enacted a child safety restraint law, the Secretary will transfer 6-10 percent of funds to the State for the implementation of child safety restraint programs. In fiscal years 2006 and beyond, if a State has not enacted a child safety restraint law, the Secretary will transfer 6-10 percent of funds to the State for the implementation of child safety restraint programs. The Secretary shall transfer 10 percent of funds apportioned to the State under sections 104(b)(1), (3), and (4) to be used for child safety restraints. The Federal share of project costs funded under this transfer is 100 percent. The amount transferred may come from various apportionments under section 104(b). The Secretary shall transfer obligation authority to the State for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs based on a determined amount. This amount is calculated by multiplying the funds transferred to the State under subsection (b) by the ratio of obligation authority distributed for the fiscal year to the total apportioned sums for highway programs. The Secretary transfers obligation authority to States for highway safety construction programs based on a determined amount. No limitation on obligations for highway safety programs applies to funds transferred under this section. Use of safety belts and child restraint systems by children is important for highway safety.
